title: Cowboy Coder
imageAlt: Excited cowboy coder shouting 'Ship it!' while surrounded by error messages
flavorText: He draws commits from the hip and merges at high noon. If it runs, it rides!

abilities.name: No Code Review Needed
description: When The Cowboy Coder completes a Feature alone, reduce the time cost by 2.
However, that Feature gains a permanent "Potential Bug" token, which can later become an actual Bug if triggered by an opponent's sabotage or random draw.

abilities.name: Glorious Quick Fix
description: Once per sprint, you may tap The Cowboy Coder to instantly fix a single Bug—but if you do, you must reveal the top card of your deck. If it's another Bug, attach it immediately to a random Feature.

title: VIM Disciple
imageAlt: A programmer in distress wearing a VIM t-shirt, surrounded by sticky notes with VIM commands, sitting at a desk with multiple open books and a glowing screen showing VIM code
flavorText: Wait, how do I quit again? Actually… let me just rebind everything.

abilities.name: Insert Mode Lock
description: Each sprint, if The VIM Disciple is "tapped", you must pay an extra Time resource to "escape". If you do not pay, The VIM Disciple remains tapped.

abilities.name: One-Shot Mastery
description: Once per game, if you invest multiple resources (e.g., Time + Morale) in a single turn, you unlock a "VIM Mastery" state for The VIM Disciple.

In VIM Mastery mode, The VIM Disciple gains a powerful buff—like fixing a Bug instantly or reducing the cost of multiple small actions in a single sprint—showing that once you really learn VIM commands, you can do everything lightning fast.

abilities.name: Ever-Growing Config
description: Whenever you attach a Tool or Framework card to The VIM Disciple (like new VIM plugins or custom macros), you may draw a card.
However, if you attach more than two in one sprint, you gain a "Configuration Bloat" token that either slows you down or increases the cost of future actions.

title: Ancient One
imageAlt: A wise programmer with a long grey beard and glowing code-reflecting glasses, wearing a brown hooded robe, sitting at an ancient FORTRAN computer surrounded by warning signs about touching COBOL code
flavorText: I wrote this before Git existed. It's version-controlled in my head.

abilities.name: The System Still Works
description: As long as The Ancient One is in play, old features cannot be removed or rewritten unless a significant resource cost is paid.
However, legacy code systems gain stability buffs, making them harder to break or sabotage.

abilities.name: That's Not How We Did It
description: Whenever a younger developer plays a Tool or Framework card, there's a chance The Ancient One rejects it outright, forcing the player to discard it or pay an extra cost to justify the change.
If the younger dev convinces The Ancient One by spending extra Morale, they gain a permanent bonus (representing earned respect).

abilities.name: Ancient Wisdom, Occasional Grumpiness
description: At the start of each sprint, you may draw a random card from the discard pile, representing deep-seated knowledge of old systems.
However, if an opponent plays a "Modernization" or "Cloud Migration" feature, The Ancient One loses morale (they hate change).

imageAlt: An enthusiastic bootcamp graduate with styled hair and goatee, wearing a teal hoodie with 'Hello World!' text, sitting at a desk with a sticker-covered laptop and surrounded by JavaScript syntax on whiteboards
title: Bootcamp Graduate
flavorText: I copied this from ChatGPT, but I totally understand it. Well... I kind of understand it. I think.

abilities.name: Tutorial-Driven Development
description: Whenever The Bootcamp Graduate attempts a Feature, flip a coin.
On heads, they complete it instantly, having found a perfect tutorial.
On tails, they get stuck and must spend an extra turn debugging Stack Overflow posts.

abilities.name: Overconfident Refactor
description: Once per game, The Bootcamp Graduate may refactor a completed Feature.
If successful, gain a small efficiency boost.
If unsuccessful, the Feature is broken and must be rebuilt from scratch.

abilities.name: Endless Certifications
description: For every Tool or Framework added to The Bootcamp Graduate, they gain a temporary +1 power for one turn.
However, if more than two are added in a single sprint, they become overwhelmed and lose their next action.

title: The Over-Engineer
imageAlt: A frantic developer at a whiteboard drawing an overly complex system diagram with microservices for every function
flavorText: Why build a simple function when you can build a distributed system with 27 microservices?

abilities.name: Microservice Mania
description: Whenever The Over-Engineer tackles a Feature, they may break it down into multiple smaller Features. Each smaller Feature grants +1 power for that sprint, but also requires double maintenance cost in later sprints.

abilities.name: Golden Hammer
description: Once per game, you may declare that a single solution you have solves all problems simultaneously. Immediately resolve one Feature for free—but attach a 'Tech Debt' token to each other Feature you own.

title: The Single Point of Failure
imageAlt: A lone engineer in a cluttered cubicle fortress, refusing to share any documentation
flavorText: If I get hit by a bus, the entire company goes under. Actually, maybe I like that power…

abilities.name: Exclusive Knowledge
description: When The Single Point of Failure completes a Feature, attach a 'Locked In' token to it. That Feature can only be modified by The Single Point of Failure.
All other developers attempting to modify that Feature must pay double Time resources or discard a random card (they have no clue how it works).

abilities.name: Undocumented Chaos
description: Once per game, you may tap The Single Point of Failure to discard an opponent’s Tool or Framework (claiming it’s incompatible).
Afterward, draw a card—representing a new black-box script you invented while nobody was looking.

title: CSS Zealot
imageAlt: A developer meticulously adjusting a design with pixel rulers and color swatches everywhere
flavorText: If it's not pixel-perfect, it's practically broken. #JustOneMore!important

abilities.name: Global !important
description: When The CSS Zealot is deployed, you may overwrite one Tool or Framework's effect with '!important'—negating its immediate downside or penalty, but doubling any future cost associated with that effect.
If an opponent tries to remove or alter this override, they must pay 1 extra Time resource (representing the headache of dealing with CSS specificity).

abilities.name: Pixel Perfection
description: Once per game, The CSS Zealot may re-roll any design or layout outcome to achieve 'pixel-perfect' status, automatically succeeding in that part of a Feature.
However, if used, The CSS Zealot gains a 'Pedantic' token that forces them to skip their next sprint while they nitpick margins and color palettes.

title: The Data Hoarder
imageAlt: A stressed developer with stacks of old hard drives and boxes labeled 'Logs 1998-2005'
flavorText: I’ve got logs going back to the dial-up era. Trust me, we’ll need them someday.

abilities.name: Relics of Data Past
description: Whenever you complete a Feature, you may attach a 'Historical Log' token to it (represented by boxes of dusty logs). Each 'Historical Log' increases that Feature's resistance to sabotage by 1.
However, if more than two 'Historical Log' tokens exist on the same Feature, it becomes 'Data Bloated,' and any attempts to modify or refactor it cost double Time.

abilities.name: Analysis Paralysis
description: Once per sprint, you may prevent an opponent from taking a new action by forcing them to 'analyze old data'—they skip their next move. You draw a card (fishing out more random data).
But if you do this more than twice in a game, The Data Hoarder becomes tapped for the following sprint (buried under 20 years of logs).

title: Meme Lord
imageAlt: A developer with an endless Slack feed, surrounded by meme-worthy notifications
flavorText: He's posted more cat GIFs than lines of code. #SoProductive

abilities.name: Instant @Channel
description: Once per sprint, you may tap Meme Lord to force another Developer to skip their next action (they're dragged into a random Slack discussion).
If the target is a Manager, gain +1 Morale (nothing better than making a boss chase Slack threads).

abilities.name: Meme Over Productivity
description: Whenever Meme Lord is untapped at the end of a sprint, place a 'Meme' token on them. For each 'Meme' token, reduce the time cost of social actions or team-building exercises by 1 (everyone's morale is artificially boosted).
However, each 'Meme' token also increases Meme Lord's future Feature completion time by 1 (they're too busy fueling the #random channel).
